“There are things you can only share with someone by fighting. For instance, how serious you are.”
--Yuuki Konno
Sword Art Online’s first season arrived in 2013 with all the storm and bluster of a Nickelback concert. It racked up massive commercial success and drew a legion of dedicated fans and haters by appealing to a very wide audience. On Western shores, SAO took on a life of its own, aided by a spectacular English dub with some relative unknowns in Bryce Papenbrook and Cherami Leigh putting together excellent breakout performances in the lead roles of Kirito and Asuna. Fans hailed its colorful cast of characters andnovel premise, while haters decried its impossibly perfect protagonist and lackluster execution. 


Personally, I stood on both sides of this “love or hate” divide, originally disliking it and growing to like it after watching it with friends. While it’s nothing too spectacular, I thought the premise was compelling, the characters eminently likable, the romance sweet without being sappy or swallowing the plot, and the action scenes well-choreographed and animated (insert ridiculous Kirito face meme here as a counterpoint). The second arc lost a lot of the head of steam the first season had established and had stripped my favorite character, the daring Asuna Yuuki, of a lot of what made her compelling, but still managed to turn it around into a satisfying conclusion.


So when Season 2 rolled around, I delayed a little in watching it until just last month to avoid having hype/hate circle-jerking poison my opinion of it. It felt like an inversion of the first season in a lot of ways. The first arc of Season 2, Phantom Bullet (or GGO, or Sinon Ass Online, whatever you want to call it) is a reintroduction to Kirito as a character, and an introduction to Shino “Sinon” Asada. Sinon is a high-ranking sniper from Gun Gale Online, which is another VRMMO game created from the “world seed” of Aincrad. The two meet while Kirito investigates the identity of a new “player-killer”, the enigmatic Death Gun, who possesses the power to kill players for real by shooting them in the game.


Phantom Bullet is also the dullest story SAO writer Reki Kawahara has told to this point. The big battle tournament has no real tension to it because you already know Kirito’s gonna win. Sinon comes off as a prickly asshole to Kirito for very little reason, and Kirito’s own motivations for entering GGO are never quite clear other than “the government asked nicely and bought me lunch”. The pace feels slow, the climax/big reveal is something of a disappointment. The only redeeming quality I can show for it is that Sinon as a character develops quickly, and Kirito is, as always, the man when it comes to action scenes. The animators at A-1 Studios know how to draw ferocious 1-on-1 sword duels, but that talent is lost on gun battles, which feel very passionless, rote, and dull.


The second arc of SAO II, if you haven’t given up after 14 episodes of GGO, is Caliber, which is a bit of a return to form and a return to the cast of Season 1 as they gear up to take down a tricky quest in ALFheim Online, the setting from season 1’s second arc. It’s mostly an excuse to dredge up characters like Suguha, Silica, and Lizbeth to actually get some screentime, but it’s alright, and seeing these characters is like coming home to old friends if you enjoyed some or all of them in the first season, as I did. Especially after 14 episodes of almost zero presence.


Caliber is two episodes long before segueing into Mother’s Rosario, the final arc of the season. As if to balance out and apologize for Phantom Bullet, we get what is definitively the best SAO story ever told, centering around Asuna and her rivalry and friendship with “Zekken”, the strongest swordsman in ALO (yes, even stronger than Kirito). I can’t spoil anything about this arc, but it deals with very serious subject matter, and the philosophy of life and the virtue of machines and virtual reality within it, with respect and heartfelt authenticity. It made the season for me. It hit me right in the feels. It made me think. And it elevated my respect for Kawahara as a writer. The OP and EDs for Mother’s Rosario are compelling visually and aurally, and gradually change as more is revealed about “Zekken” and their guild, the “Sleeping Knights”.


Visually, the show is mostly unchanged from the first season. One of the shining points of SAO for me is how it gets across the feeling of being in a video game fantasy world. The colors are bright and contrasted. The characters’ in-game avatars are sharply reminiscent of their real-life appearances but with a fantasy twist such as elf ears (or in the case of Silica, dog ears?). Which is another reason GGO disappoints me: it’s just dull to look at, having copied the brownish-tan dominant visual style of “GRIM-N’-GRITTY” American first-person shooter titles as an inspiration for its setting and character design.


Sword Art Online II is very uneven, but still has moments where it shines, sometimes brilliantly. The conclusion paves the way for further sequels and movies, much to the chagrin of its detractors, but I’ve never had a problem with something just because it’s geared for commercial success. Indeed, as a show for newcomers, I think SAO is a great representative sample of what anime is all about. Some will never watch other shows and declare that SAO is “the best ever”, and of course they are wrong, but it’s still worthy of the acclaim and following it has earned. Some will declare it a cliched mess of tropes and stereotypes, but I’ve come to the conclusion that those people hate this show just because it has reached the level of ubiquity and recognition that it has, and will never be happy with it no matter what (and usually even they do not deny that Mother’s Rosario is great).


I ultimately gave the show an 8, although it is closer to a 7.5 for me. It falls just short of the standard set by the first season because it fails to consistently be good, but the heights it reaches are much higher than those set by the first arc. Mother's Rosario is a rather daring step forward, and hopefully we will continue to see similarly ambitious arcs in the future of the series.


Until next time, continue to make your mark!

Not as good as the original SAO, but still definitely worth watching if you liked the original story. A lot of the characters from season 1 return like Klein, Lisbeth, Silica, and Kirito’s sister Leafa which I liked because I really liked all these characters and some of their character designs from season 1 have changed because now they’re all playing ALO together. Also, season 2 explores the lives of Kirito and Asuna outside of virtual reality more which was really interesting.
Characters: A new character season 2 adds is Sinon and honestly I think I may love her more than I love Asuna. Asuna andKirito are still my all-time favorite anime couple, but if I compare Sinon and Asuna as stand-alone characters I love Sinon a little bit more than Asuna. Why? First, I think if Sinon and Asuna ever got into a fight, Sinon would win. Second, I really like how serious and focused Sinon is, she really doesn’t show much emotion which I think makes her even cooler. Plus, after Kirito and Sinon team up, Sinon discovers that her and Kirito actually have a lot in common and are both trying to live knowing they did horrible things to survive. 


Death Gun, the new villain for season 2, is also awesome. I love how he kills people by appearing out of nowhere, shooting somebody, and then disappearing; it’s really ominous and creepy like you never know who he’s going to kill next. I was disappointed that I figured out who Death Gun really was before the show revealed it, but it was still cool watching Kirito play detective again while trying to solve the mystery. 


Story: The fight scenes really get better in season 2 because in GGO players fight with guns and grenades and almost all the action in season 2 is players fighting other players which is awesome. It adds bigger variety of fighting styles too because now there are snipers like Sinon, machine gun using power players, and silent assassins like Death Gun. Also, while SAO and ALO were both fantasy games, GGO is much darker and edgier like one of the battlefields in the game was this abandoned city with graffiti and rusty cars


However, I do kind of miss how in the original SAO players were trapped in the game and developed their own little lives inside the game, but now players can log out anytime so the mood of a most of the side characters is a lot less serious. Although, I guess they make up for because season 2 we get too Kirito and Asuna lives in the real world and I was actually pretty surprised to learn how hard Asuna has it with her family. 


There are 2 more story arcs after the Death Gun story arc which take place in ALO, but they aren’t quite as good as Death Gun. 


Overall: If you liked the season one of SAO, you have to watch season two.

I have read the reviews on MyAnimeList.net.  Yes, I did enjoy the first Season of SAO (Sword Art Online) with a few reservations (Side Characters left in the backdrop, the lack of resolution of major plot questions, etc...) but found the overall series enjoyable.  It basically left me wondering whether SAO II would be worth my time, and the reviews I read informed me it wasn't.  Reluctantly, after exhausting every other anime on my list from last year, I told myself "What the hey?" and decided to take a look at this series.  I'm happy I didn't let the negative reviewsdissuade me.  SAO II has its flaws, but its notable strengths are its saving grace that, at the end of the day, make the show enjoyable.


Story: 8/10  

The story is split into three separate arcs:  the Gun Gale Online, the Calibur, and the Mother Rosario arc.  


Gun Gale Online brings our ole boy Kirito and a new female character, Sinon, center stage.  Contrasting the previous sword-swinger that was the SAO world, Gun Gale... focuses on Gun combat, which makes this arc feel more like Call of Duty rather than Kingdom Hearts.  I personally found the gun fights less jaw-dropping, yet more tense.  A gain and a loss, but definitely not a net loss.  More of Kirito's harem coming along would have been nice, but the chemistry between Kirito and Sinon was well done, as well as insight into how people in this world use VMMOs to cope with reality.  For better, and for worse...   


The Calibur arc was definitely the weakest link of three.  Kirito and his gang come together again in the world of Alfheim Online.  It rings nostalgia, reminiscent of the SAO days, but without any of that foreboding-danger push that had you biting your nails in Sword Art Online, or the much needed character development many in Kirito's monster-smashing harem lack.  The arc really tries, but just comes up short.


The Mother's Rosario arc's story is where SAO II truly shines.  Asuna is the star this time (bout time, right?), and things couldn't have been better.  The arc delves more into her personal life, as well as her trials with the Sleeping Dragon Guild in their attempt to conquer a Floor Boss.  For Kirito fans, this arc will leave a sour taste in your mouth.  For fans of the show's ability to demonstrate the implications of VR's integration into our reality, this arc will be sweeter than honey.   


Art:  7/10

Strong artwork dominated for most of the viewing, but some of Kirito's combat movements in the GGO arc had me wanting to claw my eyes out (reminded me of Madara fighting the 7 Shinobi Alliance in Shippuden).  The first Opening integrates our characters' real and virtual worlds meshing beautifully and artistically, while the transition from the second Opening to its second version was refreshing and emotional.  


Sound: 7/10

They say any great soundtrack disappears subtly into the backdrop, and SAO's music gave me that appeal... perhaps a little too well.  The first opening music was strong, and probably the only one I could see myself listening to while driving down the road.  The music generally flowed well with the mood, but most of it fails to stand out.  Play it next to your Final Fantasy soundtrack, and you sadly won't be able to tell the difference.  The music does it job, but that's all.   


Character:  6/10

As usual, this is THE weakest link for this season, as it was for the first, but the crazy thing is it CAN do characterization well.  It just chooses not to do enough of it...  Yes, major points for Kirito, Sinon, and Asuna, but everyone else gets left in the dust.  Unacceptable for a seven-person team.  Why not cut that boring Calibur arc for the Beast-Tamer Loli (Keiko), or the Lovable Blacksmith (Rika), or heck, even the Chivalrous, Always-Second-Place Samurai (Klein) to have a chance to shine?  Sheesh...


Enjoyment and Conclusion:

Despite its flaws, SAO II was undoubtedly entertaining.  The action was stellar, the emotional moments will elicit sympathy and tears, the plot develops well with exciting reveals, and, when the story does decide it wants to include some backstory, it's presented concisely.  The greatest sin of SAO II, as with its predecessor, was attempting to be too many things at once, an ambitious endeavor SAO II can never quite get right.  At moments the show was an action Shonen, at others a harem, at others a romance, and at others psychological.  If SAO, both seasons, stuck with one formula or another, people would receive the show more openly for reasons of clarity, and less confusion would allow character interactions to transition better from plot-to-plot.  But then, what would SAO be?  Another .Hack Sign?  Monster?  Naruto?  Log Horizon?  By trying to hit the stars, SAO II represents what the first series did well for me:  It provided me with something different from psychology thrillers with no action, bromances lacking logical and natural female interaction, romances with only needless drama to fuel the lovers' connections.  SAO II fails to reach the heavens it aims for, but still becomes a star in its own right by the attempt.  Looking forward to season III.


Overall

Solid 8/10

Sword Art Online. It’s interesting to see how much this series have divided the anime community. Some hated the first season, others proclaim that is was the greatest thing ever. Many had mixed views. So when the second season was announced people had to see if it was going to flop in a similar way that the first season did. I for one was pleasantly surprised
STORY:
To clarify you have to watch season one of SAO to understand anything that is happening in this season. We have a new VR game called Gun Gale Online or GGO. In this world there is a player by thename of Death Gun going around and shooting players in the game, but after he shoots them they die in the real world. Kirito is called into help solve the murders as he has experience dealing with this kind of thing in SAO. He meets a highly skilled player named Shino and she gets to tag along to help solve this mystery.

Personally this arc of the story (Phantom Bullet) is very well done. It has a sprinkle of conspiracy and mystery too it that really freshend up the series to me. While it may be a little far-fetched it remains in a reasonable realm of possibility that it didn’t become a big distraction. There weren’t any times during this arch were I thought, “Wow this is so unrealistic and stupid” I was more wondering “Why is this happening and how is it happening.” Can’t believe I am saying this but it reminded me a little bit of Death Note in a way.

The second arc is about trying to get a legendary sword and honestly it is not worth talking about as it is mostly a filler arc that felt a lot more “game like” and was not entirely interesting to me.

The third arc however… wow. To me the third arc of this season was one of the most touching moments I have experienced in my short anime watching experience. In this arc Kirito passes the protagonist torch to Asuna and it was a much appreciated change. We are back in ALO and there is a player named Yuuki who is trying to find a strong player to fight. Asuna ends up helping a guild called The Sleeping Knights, their quest is to defeat a floor boss and get their names inscribed on a monument to be displayed forever. Asuna also has to deal with her mother who is disproving of her school and of Kirito. The rest of my analysis will be spoilers.

As it turns out Yuuki is terminally ill and plays VR MMOs as a way to interact with a world and feel important. The rest of the guild has similar problems as well hence the name, Sleeping Knights. Yuuki has been in a dive for over 3 years. To me this arc is very touching. Many people have health problems or social problems and use video games as an outlet. This part of the story feels extremely realistic to me and relatable. Yuuki and her friends want to leave a mark on the world, something that people will remember about them and this is their way to do it. Phantom Bullet arc also touches on games as a coping mechanism as Shino uses GGO as a way to get over her fears of handguns. I felt that these themes made this show much better than it’s prequel.


CHARACTERS

Kirito is relatively the same as before. He is prevalent in the GGO arc but becomes a side character in the later arcs. Asuna gets some good development, I enjoyed the tension between her and her mother. That felt real and semi-relatable. Shino is an interesting character. She gets plenty of screen time in the GGO arc and her backstory while somewhat far-fetched really helps explain her personality and actions. Yuuki while having a late appearance in the show makes a great impact and is honestly the most realistic character in the entire show.


ART/ANIMATION: 

Little has changed in the animation department from last season and it still holds up very well. GGO looks good and the fight scenes we very good. The art style is still good looking and holds up to some of the recent releases. No complaints in this area, see my review of season one for a larger dive into the art and animation. 

SOUND:

I skipped the OP most of the time, not this it was bad but it just wasn’t really my thing. I really enjoyed the ED of this series. Insert songs were good but we repetitive especially in ALO arcs but they are great sounding. I was impressed at the action sounds in the fight scenes and the detail that they went into with making different sounds for eat sword clash and steps even to the moving of armor. I watched this show dubbed and it was very well done. The cast of the first season reprise their roles here. I do believe that Bryce Papenbrook is becoming the new JYB as he is getting typecasted as every young angry teenage hero (which covers 90% of all action anime but I digress) 


ENDING/CLOSURE: 

To me the ending is paramount as I like closure in the shows that I watch. This ended with a short of “guess what I found something” If the story ended there I would be ranting  right now however the story has a movie that was announced that will take place after this season so that makes this section irrelevant.


CONCLUSION:

I enjoyed this season greatly, while I had many complaints about the first season this season made up for a lot of those gripes by continuing with great action and giving us a story that seems realistic and characters who are more relatable and just better written than in the first season. This show was good, and I recommend to continue watching this series.

When I first watched Sword Art Online I loved it! But once I thought more about the plot and development of characters, I felt SAO really fell short of what it could have been. Despite its issues, I still think SAO an enjoyable anime to watch.  Please knowledge that all of this is my opinion :)
*Note: I have excluded sound but I will agree that it is great!*
Characters
There are only really three new and important characters introduced in the second season, them being Sinon, death gun, and Yuuki. I'll start with Sinon. She is easily my favorite character of the entire series and herdevelopment (throughout the GGO arch) was fantastic. She is one of the only truly interesting characters from SAO in my opinion, and I found her to be incredibly unique. Her development in the first part is unrivaled by that all the other characters. Sinon drives pretty much the entirety of the show, as Kirito is useless as ever. Death Gun is also a pretty great character, and I consider the concept of his character to be stronger than the execution of his motives. I really liked how they set up the illusion of Death Gun being just a single person, and the way the mystery played out was done well. The boy (no clue what his name is) has in interesting complex and relationship to Shino (aka Sinon). Sadly, Kirito got pretty much no development for the rest of the series. The second part of the season was terrible in terms of development for side characters (literally only Yuuki and Asuna got some development). Yuuki was introduced and I honestly didn't care for her at first, actually I never really cared for her. Although the premise of her character is unique, her personality was quite bland and incredibly common. Her development was pretty good, but it sent the pace into a whirlpool of inconsistency.  I liked that Asuna finally got some development, despite the effect it had on the season as a whole. There was much better character development this season, but only for specific characters. All the side girls were ignored throughout the season, which I found stupefying. Even Sinon became a mute member of Kirito's harem-wannabe thing, which somehow undid a lot of the greatness Sinon's character built up in the first half. 



Art & Animation

The animation is pretty much on the same, awesome level as the first season. I have no complaints in this area. I would like to talk about the one new aspect that was introduced in the second season: GGO art. I actually love the darkness of GGO and how it contrasts the style of Alfheim (and SAO) completely, yet is somewhat similar to the way real life is depicted throughout the series. All in all, the art was great and saved the anime at times.



Story

Similar to last season, this season suffered horribly from inconsistent pacing. GGO had a medium pace, which I enjoyed most of all. From there, the pace took a sudden rise in the random and completely out of place Excalibur arch, which was a show of the great animation and pretty much nothing else. After that, the pace hit something like a brink wall. All of the sudden the story decided that SAO is a slow slice of life anime with a bit of gaming. Although I would not have minded a spin off, OVA, or separate season of this arch, because this arch made no sense in the context of the season. While I'll admit the character development of Asuna and Yuuki was well done, it doesn't really fit when you put it up against the GGO arch. The GGO arch is easily my favorite of the series. The premise of the story actually makes sense, as it presents the issue, the protagonist's opinion of the issue, the solution in theory, and the resolution of the issue. Although it is not a very unique structure, the details in the arch help to make it new and different from other series. The skipping between real life and the game was well done (in both arches, although especially in GGO arch), and I liked the how the arch came to an end. I also liked that the OP level of Kirito made so much more sense. He struggled with working a gun and actually has to base all of his strategy off his sword skills.This seems much more realistic and opened doors to improve upon Kirito's development.  The second half of the season was much more inconsistent in both pacing and character development. First of all, there was pretty much no premise in going to get Excalibur, as that previously (terribly weak) antagonist just kind of asked Kirito to do it without much reasoning at all. Secondly, the execution of the arch was terrible. The entire fighting scene only took about 10 minutes, which is less than one entire episode. It is just stupid to have a super hyped arch in the series if it is just rushed over and butchers the set pace, while simultaneously adds absolutely nothing new or interesting. The transition between the incredibly quick attack arch and the Yuuki arch was not smooth enough and resulted in a bizarre feel from the wack pacing. The Yuuki and Asuna arch was interesting enough in terms of plot and I don't really have too much to add because there really is nothing much to add about it. 



Season Overall

I really loved the start of the series, and felt that Sinon, Death Gun, and the GGO setting were interesting additions to the series. Despite these great new aspects, the series ruined itself in the second part of the season. The Yuuki arch was a pacing disaster that had it's moments, but was a train wreck in many ways. The horrific dialogue and lack of character development ruined the potential of the anime. Again, you see all the side characters from SAO. They get to fight a little, but otherwise get no new development. As much as I wanted to really love this season, it failed to pull through in the end.

“Engage people with what they expect; it is what they are able to discern and confirms their projections. It settles them into predictable patterns of response, occupying their minds while you wait for the extraordinary moment — that which they cannot anticipate.” - Sun Tzu, The Art of War
Get it? There's "Art" in the name. Like in Sword Art Online.
Yeah.
Sword Art Online II is considered by many to be worse than the first season, and in many places they're right. Guess what though? This guy right here likes it more because of personal preferences.
I know, it's inconceivable.
SAO II surprised me on many fronts. Most ofthe surprises were positive. Most.


*SPOILERS FOR BOTH SAO AND SAO II, YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED*


First things first, you need to know my thoughts on the first season. I didn't like it all that much, now that I look back at it. I thought the Aincrad arc was fine, if you could overlook the blatant mistakes, but I couldn't do that in the Alfheim arc. Overall, most of the stuff happened with little to no reasoning to back it up, the characters were overlooked and barely touched upon, Kirito got way too powerful way too fast, and never gave up, Asuna turned into Princess Peach in the second half, the rape scenes triggered me immensely (don't remind me of that tentacle scene, for the love of God), Yui was a forced character that I liked, though at times it was pretty clear that they were trying to push this "family" idea way too hard. There were a few more mistakes, but I'm not about to write a review on that, so I'll move on.




Story: 4

This time around we get three arcs, though one is pretty much a filler.

First one revolves around Gun Gale Online, which is an MMOFPS. A guy named Death Gun is shooting people, which somehow causes them to die in real life. Kirito gets peer pressured into stopping him by a guy that works in the virtual world danger prevention department, or something like that. Where was he in the last season? Oh, he was there, but we only see him in flashbacks here. The author pretty much adds shit that never happened into the first season, because of plot convenience.Same thing with the nurse, that supposedly treated Kirito when he was in the game. Before he enters however, we get a chance to meet the main grill for this arc: Sinon. More on her, later. We get a couple of backstory episodes, which are fine. They at least try to build up character, and it worked for me. After that Kirito finally joins the game, in which he looks like a girl for reasons. He randomly meets Sinon, who of course thinks he's a girl, and they go shopping for the big tournament that's coming up. But Kirito doesn't have any money. So he gets them by becoming Jesus-kun.

For the first time in the series I was actually pissed off by how overpowered he is. Sure, there was a lot of moments where I almost cracked, but this was.... bad. Kirito, who supposedly never played this game before, is able to dodge bullets at will. He got the money by beating a game in which a machine shoots bullets randomly. Apparently this game is pretty much unbeatable, but not for Kirito.

After that, he becomes a jedi, drives on a bike that is supposedly almost impossible to control, enters the tournament, sees Sinon strip and finally we get to see him in action.

He wins, obviously, but in a way that made me laugh so hard, that I didn't think I can get angry at this anime anymore. Let me put it like this: Kirito enters a tournament in a FPS, and he wins by doing flips, slashing his opponents and reflecting their bullets with a lightsaber. Kirito is literally a jedi, but occasionally uses a gun, which you can consider his force power.

Now for the best part. After the first round, Kirito is approached by Death Gun himself. He recognized him, so of course that means that he must be from SAO! We are shown a few clips of all the people that Kirito met in the previous season. Of course, my instinct tells me that it will be one of them, so I was looking forward to figuring out who is hiding under the mask (Oh, I didn't mention, Death Gun is hiding under a mask, breathing heavily every once in a while. If you can't make the connection, you need to watch more Star Wars). But guess what? I couldn't. Why?

BECAUSE THE AUTHOR ADDED A SCENE TO THE FIRST SEASON AGAIN.

This time it's a more serious problem though. Apparently, Kirito, Asuna, Klein and a group of knights assaulted the base of Laughing Coffin, the player killing guild from the first season, during their time in  Aincrad. In that assault, couple of knights died. Kirito kills a few of the murderers in rage as well. Death Gun turns out to be one of the survivors from that assault. Sure, it's a cool scene that gives Kirito a room to grow and all, but adding it in the second season is ridiculous. At this point it almost felt like everything that happened before was unimportant, because they could just add something to the story any time they wanted. 

This was the first triggering moment. I couldn't stand it. This felt like a bitch slap to the face of all the Aincrad arc fans, but since I didn't care about it all that much, I moved on hoping nothing like this happens again.

Kirito eventually gets to duel Sinon. He walks up to her like a 90's movie star, with all her bullets flying past him, and after a short talk, he did something impossible once again and won.

At this point I gave up on Kirito as a character. From this point on I just saw him as the infamous Jesus-kun.

During a break from the game, we get to see Sinon being pissed at Kirito, but a good friend of hers hugs her and confesses his love. I really didn't want to mention this guy, but it's necessary. Sinon pushes him back, for reasons I will discuss in the characters section. Before we jump back in we also witness Kirito confessing his flashbacks of killing people in game to the nurse, but I didn't care, because of the whole concept surrounding it.

The main tournament - Bullet of Bullets - eventually starts. After a while Sinon teams up with Kirito. Death Gun kills another guy, and they try to hunt him down. They end up in a town, Sinon gets stunned, Kirito saves her, they try to run away, but they are being chased. Miss sniper can't shoot, because of trauma, but thankfully, one touch from Jesus-Kun makes her forget it.

They end up in a cave. A few fan service scenes and a short talk later, Jesus Sherlock-kun uncovers the truth about the real life killings. It's actually quite smart and interesting, though still a bit unbelievable. Let's just say, that there is a high chance, that someone could see what was going down, after all somebody has to break into a house in order to commit the murder. After that, they come up with a plan. With only four people left, Kirito will act as a decoy, and Sinon will shoot the remaining guy and try to kill Death Gun. The first part miraculously works, but the second one only gets rid of the villain's  rifle, and the scope on her own gun.

Now, on to the biggest, most ridiculous finale of an arc I've ever seen.

Kirito confronts Death Gun. He tells him that there is no way he'll win, because he doesn't know his name from SAO. A good old sword fight commences. Jesus-kun at first gets completely destroyed, but he finally recognizes him. He sees the red eyes on his mask. Yes, the ones he saw before, when he was standing right in front of him. Death Gun stops moving, but Sinon somehow manages to aim at him without a scope, from a ridiculous distance, at that exact moment, so Kirito can defeat the bad guy and come out victorious. He meets up with his companion and they die together from a grenade explosion. Sinon decided that it would be for the best if they would win together, but because she is scared that someone might be at her house, she reveals her house address to Kirito before ending it.

But it doesn't end here. It gets worse. Much worse.

Sinon wakes up, and a moment later someone is at her door. It's the guy that tried to hug her before. Turns out he's not only Death Gun's brother, but also a freak that wants to rape her. He threatens her with the syringe filled with deadly poison. She tries to run, but gets caught at the door. After that, Jesus-kun shows up to save the day, but he gets injected. Sinon hits the assailant in the head, and then we witness the Resurrection of Jesus-kun. Out of all the places on his body, he got injected in a place where an electrode from the hospital didn't fall off. Yes, he's not dead, but he was pretending to be in a state of agony for the dramatic effect just a second before that.

This was the most triggering conclusion to a story I've ever endured. If not for Sinon, I think I would have actually dropped it. Thankfully, the next arcs weren't filled with this amount of noticeable plot conveniences for me.

After it all calms down, they present some Sinon moment and Kirito using a device that can make Yui feel like she's in the real world, through the use of cameras and some computer program. It makes sense, after all Kirito decided that he will study that stuff, and it's not unseen for a youngster to make a scientific discovery, so I can let that slide.


The second arc is harmless, so I won't talk about it as much.

Kirito, Asuna, Sinon, Lisbeth, Sillica, Suguha, Klein and Yui decide to go into a dungeon in Alfheim to obtain the strongest sword in the game. There is really not much to say, they just decide to complete a quest together. It's harmless, and has barely any impact on the entire story. At first I thought this would serve as an introduction for the Alfheim Cat-Girl Sinon in Alfheim, but it ended up being nothing much. Everyone had their little moment, and that's about it. I don't really understand why was this necessary, but it was okay.


Now, at this point, the story was a two in my eyes. I praised it here and there, but some moments made me feel so bad, that I just wanted to get it over with. How did it get  a boost like this in just on arc? The answer is: Something different.

Throughout the entire SAO up to this point, the main thing that the creators kept focusing on, was the game. Here, we have a pretty much perfect correlation between the virtual world and the real world. It's not like this hasn't been touched upon in the series before (Sinon and Kyouji trying to escape into the game, trying to bring Yui into the real world) but this time it was much more effective. Sure, it made most of the same mistakes, but in some other areas, it made me wonder, how did the same person write the first arc, and this one.

First thing I noticed is the fact that the MC of these last few episodes is Asuna. THANK GOD. Kirito did all he could, the best way to utilize him at this point was exactly the thing they did - turning him into a side character.

Back to the story. A new challenger approaches.... I mean, some person is challenging strong people, and promising an unique sword skill in exchange. Not only that, but that mysterious swordsman..... DEFEATED JESUS-KUN! But don't worry, he was only defeated because he wasn't giving it his all, so that's fine. I swear, making Jesus-kun the best at everything needs to stop.

In the real world, Asuna's parents, mostly her mother, want her to move to a different school, and stop going out with Kirito. This was handled surprisingly well and felt like an everyday family argument. It was stated that Asuna had not been in the greatest of relationships with her family before as well.

Asuna goes to take up the challenge in the game, turns out, the swordsman a girl. One intense battle later, Asuna is asked to join her party consisting of her guild members - "Sleeping Knights" - in order to beat a floor boss in Aincrad, and get their names written down on a certain stone wall.

After a test run with the boss, they realize that they being spied on in order to find the boss's weakness. They quickly come back to do it for real this time, but they aren't the first ones at the entrance this time. A group of 20 other people, just waiting for the rest of their teams, is blocking the way. Asuna and the team decide to fight, but a huge group of players appears behind them. Just as all hope is lost, Kirito wallruns in front of them and takes them on. JESUS-KUN IS BACK, AND HE IS GOING TO SAVE EVERYONE. Oh, and Klein's there too....

Sleeping Knights beat the assholes blocking the way, defeat the boss, and go to celebrate in Asuna's house ingame. She asks to join their guild, and they refuse with sad expressions on their faces. In order to cheer everyone up, they go to check out that stone wall. Yuuki calls Asuna "sister", but when she points it out to her, she quickly logs out, acting pretty terrified while doing so.

This is the point where the in game events start to connect more and more with the real world. Asuna doesn't know what's going on, but Kirito tells her to go to a certain hospital. This makes sense because of his studies as well. When she arrives there, she is faced with the horrible truth.

Yuuki has a terminal illness. This was obvious to me, because of how she was acting, the guild getting disbanded and Yuuki's reactions, but the degree of pain that she felt, the sadness and despair she had to face made me tear up. She has AIDS, but while normally it isn't terminal, this time around it's a very specific type of AIDS. She has been struggling for 15 years, she had to move because other children made fun of her illness,  and after getting worse, she had to stay in bed all the time, watching her parents her sister and her friends pass away while she was also slowly dying, trying to live the fullest inside a virtual reality. Yuuki was brave enough to take part in a medical experiment, that caused her to stay inside the virtual world for three years, completely cut out from the real world.

Some may say that it's just piling up misfortune to force the viewer into crying, but I highly disagree. When someone in real life is faced with a similar situation, it often goes terribly as well. Sure, this is an extreme situation, this does not always happen, but I've seen such tragedies unfold before, and that made the impact even harder.

I want to mention the little moment I had after that scene. Everything just suddenly clicked: Yuuki's childish behavior, her being really serious only during fights, the image she had of herself inside her head looked like her younger appearance, instead of her current one. All that turned this one moment into one of my most memorable anime experiences. I have to give the creators praise for that.

Getting back on track now, Yuuki's one dream is to go to school again, so Asuna comes up with an idea to use the device that got Yui into the real world on her. Her dream comes true, enough said. Later on, we also see that the home she used to live in is going to be sold. The bond between Asuna and and Yuuki strengthen, but at this point everyone knew that the terminal illness will ruin the happy moments.

Thanks to the Yuuki's strength to push on, Asuna also gathers strength to confront her mother about moving schools. She does so by showing her the virtual world that she found love in. Asuna reminds her of the parents she neglected because of work and prestige. Asuna ultimately gets the permission to stay at her school and go out with Kirito. Everything ends happily.

I wish.

We get to see a few more happy scenes of Yuuki and all the characters we met in the series having fun. There's a little  of some tournament, in which Yuuki comes out victorious, defeating Jesus-kun again, but only because the time ran out, don't worry.

A few days later Yuuki's state is critical. She's dying. She wanted to spend her last moments in the real world, but when Asuna arrives at her side, she want to go back. In Alfheim, at the place where they first met, she gives Asuna her special skill, called Mother's Rosario. Pretty touching name, as few moments later it's revealed that she believed in God. She collapes, Asuna holds her head. A very memorable quote is present here, I feel obliged to bring it up: "God would never put us through all this suffering if he didn't think we could bear it." She believed that this isn't anyone's fault. She took all the pain like an adult would.

Her guild arrives. Another really well directed and touching scene hits, as one of the members that used to be cheeky and smiley tries to be her usual self, but bursts into tears in the middle of the sentence out of nowhere.

Tears started flowing down my face.

Kirito and friends also arrive, followed by a crowd of players. Everyone bows for the best swordsman in the game.

Yes, the drama was forced, yes, Yuuki was introduced just to die, but shit like this happens every day, it's not as over glorified, but every day you can meet a person with cancer, that's going to die soon. I could not look at this in the same way I look at all other deaths, if it's for that reason only. I've seen people die of cancer, I can't forget that. The whole scene was directed very well, but if you didn't care, it will look forced, I have no way to deny it.

At Yuuki's funeral we see that one of her guild members is no longer in terminal condition and can attend it. Data from Yuuki's time in the machine is going to be used to help humanity, and the system that Kirito created will be  as well. Turns out that the device was created by Kayaba Akihiko, in a yet another attempt to make me sympathize with the villain that killed 4000 people.


I feel like I need to mention a few lesser mistakes that I noticed. They didn't tamper with my enjoyment too much, but they were definitely there:

Asuna, Kirito, Sinon, Yuuki, and everyone lives in the same city. I don't know if this is just how the universe works, but I find it highly unlikely that there is just one town in Japan where people play MMO's. It was stated that players all over the world play them.

Asuna and Kirito's relationship was pushed aside to the point that it was barely noticeable. It's supposed to be the main reason why Asuna doesn't want to leave, but she doesn't even talk about it with him. I get it that she doesn't want to do it, but he should notice something's wrong even before the whole Yuuki situation. He's Jesus Sherlock-kun after all.

They tried to hard to develop high stakes, especially in the second arc. "There's only a sliver of light left, you have to hurry.", "Oh no there is only a half o a sliver..." Stuff like that. Same thing with he first season, instead of health we have light.

There is still no explanation how to character feel tired or cold, or how do they taste stuff. Does the brain send signals to the body? I guess so, the pain levels at the end of first arc would hint that, but what about fatigue? Why do they breath heavily after running down the stairs or stuff like that?

I find it hard to believe that a school girl was threatening someone with a real gun, and was willing to shoot scared Sinon with it. I can't understand why someone would be this stupid, what if the gun didn't have the safety lock was on? Would she just shoot and kill her in the process?

There's a few more, but those are the most noticeable out of the lesser ones.


While the first arc was a disaster, and the last one also didn't avoid mistakes, without the time skips the pacing felt better and a lot of scenes were directed in a way that was more believable than the ones in the first season. It's hard to tell if the story was better than before, but I preferred the second season personally. Maybe it's because of the "forced" drama, I'll never know.


Art: 7,5

Not much has changed from the first season, if something the action scenes looked a bit better, but that balances out with the horrible looking CGI floor from the opening and the first Sinon scene. The bosses CGI this time around as well, and it looked much nicer. It was flashier in a good way, and darker when it needed to be, especially in GGO. Really liked the art style there.

Animation is stellar, there were no weird frames this time around, or they were hidden better. The movement looks like it should, the faces move in a more realistic way, as I mentioned, there was this one really great looking scene of the Sleeping Knights member bursting into tears.

An improvement, a small one, but it's there. Seems like the budget helped in this area.


Sound: 7

On the other hand, we have the recycled music. A lot of the tracks are just remixes, don't get me wrong, I like "Light up your sword" even more than I liked Luminous Sword, but it would be nice to hear a few more originals. When they're there though, they're not bad, and the original SAO had great music. I'd say that it's a downgrade, but by a small margin.

The openings are great, I especially like "Ignite" because it captures the feel of an FPSMMO rather well. It mixes in some fantasy-like sounds like a violin, but mostly it uses a lot of electronic guitar. Great stuff, got me pretty hyped every time I heard it. "Courage" is also good, fits the slower pacing of the second half. I like both. The endings are nothing to write about though. They're fine at best.

I'm not the one to judge seiyuus, as I'm not sure what makes a good one, but Yoshitsugu Matsuoka as Kirito and Miyuki Sawashiro as Sinon make a great pair. They sounded great together. I wish we heard more dialogues from the two of them.


Characters: 6

The cast didn't work well off of each other, but individually some of them could be fun. A few pairs worked well, like Kirito and Sinon, or Asuna and Yuuki. I'll go more in depth.

Kirito - He's a failure. I'm sorry, but this time around even I couldn't justify him being an overpowered, bland character. I wouldn't say he was bad, but unlike in season 1, I had nothing to look forward to in terms of his development, nothing intrigued me about his future. There wasn't much to write about in the first season either, but here he turned into your generic MC, that had some pretty laughably stupid moments here and there. Sometimes it wasn't the fault of the character though, the author failed to give him a proper motivation and opted out by just adding a scene to the Aincrad arc. That led to his motivation being completely irrelevant to me. At some point I just gave up on him.


Asuna - As an MC she works far better than Kirito does. She still had room to grow as a character, so I'm glad they chose to give her some more screen time in the second half. She was my favorite character from the first season because she could be a strong, independent love interest when needed. That was ruined a bit in the second half, but here she doesn't rely on Kirito all the time. She shows signs of independence once again, and I liked that. She wasn't clinging onto Kirito, which may have ruined their bond a little bit, but helped her develop. She went through a positive improvement in my book.


Sinon - I expected another Suguha, where the fanservice and wanting Kirito's virtual and real life body would be the only defining characteristics (Don't get me wrong, the fanservice was there, but it wasn't defining in my eyes), but instead I absolutely loved her character. She was cool in game, and seemed lost in the real world. She interacted with everyone in a fun way that never failed to entertain me. Her weapon of choice was awesome. I loved her designs in all areas. We got to see her at a certain point in her development, and ended at a strong point, that still leaves room for growth. Her backstory provided enough for me to care, and all the scenes with the guns later on showed that she is still afraid, but getting stronger. She had a few funny scenes too. Long story short: I love everything about her character. She is the only reason why I enjoyed the second half of the GGO arc.


Death Gun - A horrible villain, I'm still debating whether I found him worse than Sugou or not. He's like a Disney villain, he does bad because he's evil. Actually, I think that's an insult towards Disney, so I take it back. He's unlike any other villain, he doesn't have a motivation, he didn't do it because of vengeance towards Kirito, he just likes to kill people. His identity felt like a slap to the face. I hate him.


Kyouji - Don't even get me started. At least he has a motivation, I guess, that being wanting to be the best GGO player and being mad. I feel like they could have just made him into a cold blooded villain, instead of being mentally ill, because that rape scene looked disgusting, and not in a good way. To be honest, I was surprised by the reveal, but if I looked at the opening instead of just listening to it I could have figured him out.


Yuuki - A character apparently introduced only to die and force feelings down my throat. I think that's going too far. Just like Sinon, we get to see her at a certain moment in her development, more specifically at the end of it. There wasn't much room for her to grow, but she was a pleasant addition to the cast. Unlike Yui, her childish behavior was justified entirely, she simply didn't grow up because of her condition, and her calling Asuna "sister" has been built up and had a visible impact. Of course she's not perfect, and if someone won't like her instantly, they won't like her at all. I feel like I explained my reasons well enough before, so I'll end this here.


Klein - The only side that I want to write about, because he was turned into a comic relief, and I found that to be a bad idea. I can't believe that someone thought that turning him into a guy desperately looking for a girl, even it's an NPC, is a good idea. It came out silly, but once again, not in a good way.


The second arc expanded a bit on Leafa, Lisbeth and Sillica, but very little so I don't feel like I need to write about them.


The cast isn't strong, but in each arc I had enough to keep me invested. Sinon and Yuuki were the main reasons, but Asuna was a decent MC for the third arc. The rest ranges from meh (Lisbeth, Sillica) to annoyingly poor (Death Gun). Unlike parts of the story, I didn't hate any character to the point of me wanting to quit. I have many problems, but I wouldn't want any character gone, I'd just want them fixed.


Enjoyment: 7

This is a weird case, because I usually rate the anime that triggered me this hard pretty low on enjoyment, but at the same time, I rate the anime that made me cry higher. Taking everything into consideration though, I enjoyed the GGO setting at the very least, Sinon is now one of my favorite characters, Yuuki's story was heartbreaking and it had a much better pacing. Other than the specific moments, nothing tampered with my enjoyment, while during the first season, I was constantly annoyed. Not to mention a few cool moments, like the fight between Death Gun and Kirito itself (not the conclusion), or Sinon's introduction. Seven seems fair.


Overall: 6

I don't really consider this season good, but I do consider it special in a way that's seriously hard to explain in just a few words. There were quite a few moments and characters that I didn't expect from a series that insisted on punching me in the face as a viewer. I would have never thought it would make me cry, or even care about anyone, considering that I found the first season not good enough to even continue watching the series straight away. It took me some time to get into it, but I think it was worth it. With that being said, I'm still mad about all the mistakes it did. I will not overlook them. Sure, this season gave me the strength to continue watching the series, but it still wasn't a good experience. The writer still pulls off mistakes that anyone who watched more than 10 anime could fix if they thought about if for longer than ten minutes. At times it felt as if the creator didn't believe in his project. The only thing  I have to say towards the people who made this, is:

"Shut up, and take my six"


As always, this is purely my opinion, and I encourage you to develop your own.

*Minor Spoilers*
So after re-watching this season again, I can admit that it is no masterpiece, but it does evoke a strong core with better characters and story-lines that the first season seemed to be missing entirely. Let me explain myself and redeem this anime.
To start, there are three "arcs" in this anime. You have Gun Gale Online, Caliber, and Mother Rosario. Gun Gale Online is a brand new VRMMO that introduces guns and mostly PVP. The story behind it is about a player who calls himself "Death Gun" and who holds the power to kill players in the game, just like how Sword Art wasdone. Kirito was summoned by someone who works for the government and who does research on VRMMO's. He asks Kirito to dive into Gun Gale Online and solve the mystery. That's basically the premise for Gun Gale, and well, it get's half of it right. To start, Gun Gale is my second favorite arc in the Sword Art Online series, mainly because they introduce a character who is by far the most interesting character in all of Sword Art Online, Sinon. Sinon has a very dark, but interesting enough backstory for her to impact what is going on while Gun Gale Online takes place. It all works in favor for what Kirito experiences during this time, but I feel like it was a bit cliche at times. The main problem I have with Sinon, and not as her character, but the fact that we have to get ass shots of her left and right. It just seems so degrading to do something like that to such a good and honest character to the show. In the end Kirito still holds the most power and seems totally OP, but this slowly degrades from there for him.


Then we're stuck with the last two Arc's: Mother Rosario & Caliber. Caliber was basically a huge filler to show how badass Kirito is, even though we have already established that a million times over. And while it does have an honest story to it, it's rather boring. Now onto the best part of ALL Sword Art Online: Mother Rosario. While not spoiling much, it's a very tragic story about a girl named Yukki and her party who want to make it onto a giant plaque that is situated in ALO for their memories in-game. Asuna get's a solid back story here, and we get a very emotional ride as we see many things take place that Sword Art Online has never really shown. And honestly somewhat redeems Sword Art Online for me.


Now onto the art & sound. Both are done very well, and the foley and atmospheric sounds they use are phenomenal. But the scores are kinda stale and feel used.


I know that many people dislike this series SOLELY because of Kirito, but I feel that he changes to be less of an ego-maniac, and more of a chill dude who becomes more balanced as the show progresses. Kirito from Sword Art Online, all the way to about the end of Caliber Arcs', seems to be way over-powered and unnecessary. While he does pose as a bad-ass, it just seems very unreal for someone to accomplish all of the things he does in these arc's. But this all changes slowly, as we start to see other players that are as powerful, or more powerful than he is. Asuna is the first person to demonstrate that, but we also see this with Sinon, Yukki, and many more characters who have an edge over Kirito. As for the other characters, Yui get's to be introduced to the real world, and we get to see how tech in this world evolves. Suguha & the lot don't really get more backstory, if any at all, but I feel that they will eventually delve into this later.


So all in all, this Anime is NOT as bad as people say. Sure it has problems, but re-watching it again about a year later, I can tell you that it evolves into something pretty unique toward the end. While there are many cliche moments and things that happen, it's not all bad, and actually kinda funny. I recommend you give this a try, don't give this a bad review just because everyone else says it's bad, give it a try.

SAO 2 - Even though it really doesnt have much in common with that name, tries to follow-up with our lovely Jesus-kun and his very decent harem in this by many unwanted continuation of by many considered great first half of SAO 1. If you expect another original setting and promising ideas like from first half of SAO 1, you will be dissapointed, but still overall it keep some quality that makes this show still watchable, even though story wont stuck in your head for more than you watched it unfortunately.
Light spoilers...
Story - 4
Dont expect any miracles here - It's fanfiction level of writting, alot of dumb one-liners and overall lack of any major point of entire season as whole. The thing is that main driving force in SAO 1 was that everything was "real" - you died in the game, you are dead for good. SAO 2 never reached that feel of constant fear, it just tries it by dumb "you cant log off while in tournament" which is nonsense considering the world now knows better after SAO incident. 

So first story arc actually starts pretty promising - new VR game - steampunk setting and new problem - some guy cosplaying Darth Vader is having gun that apparently can kill players in real life. Nonsense, right ? So let's call Jesus-kun, a.k.a. Kirito, the underaged kid to solve these murders because that's how things in Japan works I guess... Anyway, later it turns up that things were much simplier. Kirito finds himself in the GGO as a female looking avatar (because reasons) then runs into his new harem member n.5564. Despite anime tries a lot to care about this harem girl and their relationship, adding a lots of teasing, and most of the time it actually works - the problem is - we have been over this over and over. With Asuna, who is now Kirito's girlfriend and where pretty much romance progresion died in SAO. You knew from the begining of the second part of SAO 1 and so as here that it wont go anywhere with these harem girls for one use. First act ends with Sinon joining harem fanclub, end thats where her part in the whole story ends - just an another girl that comes after Asuna. She did her part as simple emotional bait.

And the main vilan ? I have to give credit to creators, I had some good laugh over there (if that was the intention).


Second act is just a filler, doesnt even worth watching, just so MC can be even more OP as he already is.


Third act is a strange one. It heavily plays on melodrama, so it depends if this your cup of the tea or not. I think melodrama can be done well if is not overused, not where it shoudn't be or where we dont care about characters enough, and this it that case. It's really nice to see different MC for a change - Asuna. The entire plot is about her meeting up with one unknown group of players that really want the beat the boss and "they wont be much around after spring" so they want to do it ASAP. You know something is not right after these "subtle" hints, and you will see the "plot twist" from mile away. I really dunno about this, it just feels kinda out of the place, really forced, just for them to introduce this one character to just later... also there is this sub-plot revolving about Asuna and her mother relationship, pretty generic "do what we want from you, it's for your best" done over and over. Thats it. Also Jesus gets his ass beaten so its not that bad part, it had it's moments, also yuri baiting. 

But same goes for first arc. There are good moments, but overall anime just feels all over the place like one gaint messy epilogue to SAO 1 which doesn't know where to go.


Art/Sound - 8/9 


Yeah, you cant deny the production quality of this anime. Both beautiful backgrounds of steampunk GGO and amazing musical score makes this really a glorified fanfiction.


Character - 4


Lets start with the our savior - Kirito. Once again (except third act) he is a perfect human being with his own harem, with super skills that comes without much efford, etc... Only change is that the writer tried to give him PTSD, but the result is dull and forced since we have seen him before pretty OK with his past. But anime needed something for him with he can relate to Sinon - therefore sudden delayed minor PTSD that washes away like his harem member into background.


Sinon - introverted girl, having some dark memories from the past, with real PTSD, being bullied in school and having that  o n e  nice guy (hahah). But she is overall fine and interesting, enough for you to care about her. The problem is that after her work for plot is done, she is put away into harem storage room, where she wont get any more screentime to conclude her relationship and character.


Asuna - Not much to write here. She only acts as girlfriend in act one and in act three she is pretty much blank character, portlayed only as that girl that cares, from who's perspective we are watching the melodrama. They trying also for some character development with her, but it doesnt working very well.


Klein - comedic relief


Harem storage room - bunch of girls left over just being in the background


Nice guy - Sinon's fedora guy, that actually went too far


Gman - Japan's version of evil gman that is using 17 years old kids to do his job


Enjoyment - 7


Its glorified fanfiction with big production value. It's decent anime to watch when you are looking for something simple and you don't have many options.


Overall - 6 


+ Great audiovisual

+ Sinon and Asuna

+ Good moments in first arc and its promising setting

- Cheap MC 

- Story all over the place

- Most of the cast unused and left over

"Some say this series is 'overrated' and 'horrible.' I decided to try it and not jump on the bandwagon, and I'm glad I didn't drop it." 
                                                                          -Some random guy on theinternet


I've been putting this anime off for literally 4 years because all the rumors on the internet saying SAO2 was horrible. I've seen so many anime that I've run out of popular ones to watch, so I finally decided to check this off my list and write a short review.

I'll start off with saying that if you didn't like the first season and don't like the MMORPG scene then Sword Art Online 2 probably isn't for you, and the same can be said for this short review since I'll be writing on the assumption you've seen and liked the first season and also like MMORPGs.


The plot summary on MAL to SAO2 really only applies till the end of episode 14. After that it's pretty much just a wrap up for the series in ALfheim Online (ALO), the fairy virtual reality world. Episodes 1-14 are in Gun Gale Online (GGO) which has a more serious atmosphere and where you get to see Kirito (Kirigaya) do his typical badass stuff.

Basically what happens is some guy is able to kill people in the real world in GGO, someone with the government is assigned to deal with it, luckily this person is acquaintances with Kirito through the SAO incident, the government man goes to Kirito since he knows Kirito is experienced with the virtual world, and gives Kirito a job to stop Death Gun (the guy killing people in real life through the game).

It's a gun type MMO but Kirito chooses a light saber type weapon. A lot of people complain about this and how it's crazy how Kirito can just run at people shooting him and knocking their bullets out of the air, but it honestly made sense to me. All the virtual worlds are based on the same "world seed" from SAO which makes it possible for people to convert their accounts over and retain their skills/levels. And as we all know, Kirito was a badass in SAO and ALO, being a speed demon among other things. There could also be other factors like GGO using different variables for bullet speed than in real world. You see it happen all the time in gun games. It makes the game more fair.


The story for the first half was pretty nice. I was entertained and we even get introduced to a new character called Sinon (Shino). The anime kept focusing on both her and Kirito but it worked out pretty well. The other half (episodes 15 and up) was a nice reintroduction to all the characters. It was like a planned goodbye to us. At the end the feels were real, man.


The art was more or less the same old. They did have pretty CGI though.


Sound was normal. Voice actors, the music, all of it.


Characters could have been better, especially when it came to Kirito. It felt too forced on him when they were trying to make him "grow" but it's easy to ignore since we already know how much growing he did in the first season. Shino and Asuna felt more realistic though. They overcome their hardships instead of trying to rely solely on other people, and grow as a result.


I enjoyed Sword Art Online 2, same as I did for Sword Art Online. Maybe it's because I enjoy MMORPGs and am hoping for virtual reality that is as advanced as it is in this anime to become real. That and I just love badass main characters that take everyone by surprise with how powerful they are after the enemy underestimated them. Guess that's why Overlord and Densetsu no Yuusha no Densetsu are my favorite "overpowered MC" type anime.


tl;dr if you liked Sword Art Online then you'll like this second season since the first arc focuses on Kirito being a badass with a light saber in a gun MMO to find a murderer and the last arc is a beautiful farewell to us from all the characters we know and love.

Sword Art Online is the worst anime of all time. I hated the first one with a passion, and it is only thanks to my friend's recommendation that I decided to watch the 2nd one. To my great surprise, I was enjoying it quite a bit at the start.
In the second season of Sword Art online, we are introduced to a character named Sinon, who actually had some depth. Keyword: HAD. She is completely relatable in the sense that she's bookish and traumatized in real life but turns into a complete badass in a game. While this is not a character trait unique to Sinon(and is in fact quite a cliche), she has a personality and an interesting history that would have been enough to carry a bad anime across the line of mediocrity. Hell, give her some character development, she might even make an otherwise mediocre concept/anime "good." She would've been a good lead. She was doing a good job being the protagonist.   


Then Kirito showed up. And everything went to absolute Shit.  


All her character developments are abandoned. The story of how Sinon overcome his fear of men and gun turned into the story of how Kirito got himself another waifu. And the things that he did with Sinon, the things that he said, actually made me feel uncomfortable. He was pretty much flirting with Sinon and cheating on his girlfriend, but somehow it's okay because it's Kirito. 


He's the hero. You're supposed to like him. He can do no wrong.

At this point, I'm sure the only time I'm ever going to enjoy Sword Art online is when Kirito either straight-up dies or they do a spin-off without Kirito coming to save the day every damn time in some stupid manner.


The biggest problem with sword art online wasn't the premise or the story or the art or the music or the bizarre things that occurred. The biggest problem with Sword Art Online is Kirito.  Always has been, and always will be.  


Overall, I'd say Sword Art online 2 is a bad anime. Not the worst anime of all time. There are some enjoyable moments, a decent new heroine who has an interesting (by SAO standard) backstory, but when the show throws everything out of the window just so the old protagonist can get the girl in the end, it's doomed to be a less than mediocre anime that should be watched by no one.

I didn't mind the first season of SAO but when I watched this season I quickly got a bad taste in my mouth.
Story 
In the first half the story was alright (but I'm leaving the stupid character for later)
There did bring back the death element but this time only one character has the ability to kill. Also there was no tension, no character that the main has known has been killed which, in turn, killed the tension, if they had killed a character like Liz or Klein in the first series then there *may* have been tension. Also there is no way Kirito is thatgood in a game he just started playing, with a sword, IN A SHOOTER! Also the prediction lines are the dumbest things in a shooter, if you want a mechanic like that, make the bullets slower, if you have prediction lines, all you have to so is move out of the way and don't get me started on the "predicting the prediction line." What was with the side story? It was a pointless quest for a sword (not like Kirito has enough) and nothing impactful happened, it was filler... On a series that didn't need filler.

Art

Sound

Character

Sinon's friend only had a personality when he was trying to rape Sinon.


All the characters from the last arc could've been interesting characters if it took the episodes from the filler and used that time to develop these characters but we didn't get that, instead we get a story focused on Asuna.


Enjoyment/Overall


The first season I enjoyed watching even if it wasn't the best anime but I would've dropped this season really quickly if I didn't hear that the last arc was good, which I disagree with.

I did not enjoy myself when watching this, instead I was having the opposite of enjoyment, which is a first for me.

I rewatched both seasons over the past month; most of my viewing was done within the past 2 weeks since I was busy earlier on.  I still loved the series even after a few months went by. The Fairy dance arc is my least favorite arc, but it's still very good and Alfheim is the center for so many things later on in the story. Sinon was definitely a good addition.  Kirito needed a friend who wasn't another SAO survivor and she was strong (in the game anyway) and fiery and it fit her role perfectly.  I loved the action and I enjoyed seeing Kirito adapt his in game sword skills in order to use them in a gun game and succeed.  One of my favorite scenes is when he cut Sinon's hecatete bullet in half.  They also made a good and took care of Death Gun. Kirito also helped bring Sinon out of her shell in the real world.


The Calibur arc was short, but enjoyable.  It was nice to see a story arc based around Excalibur after it was previously introduced and I really enjoyed the boss fights in the arc.  The Mother's Rosario arc was great too.  Asuna is my favorite female in the show so I like how they showed more development for her. The music is always fantastic along with the art as well.
